About us, clients in English
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Clients {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "about" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > About us > Clients {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

ABOUT US

  • Blog
  • Partners
  • Clients
  • HNI

Human Network International builds the capacity of development partners to collect data and make better decisions.

Featured clients:

The World Bank and the Government of Madagascar

The Government of Madagascar hired HNI for two separate projects using World Bank loans. The first was to create an application for the Ministry of Health to collect stock information for life-saving HIV drugs using SMS from a network of doctors authorized to administer the medications. The second was to work with the National Nutrition Office to collect monthly activity report data using SMS from a large network of community-based nutrition agents.
www.worldbank.org

Marie Stopes Madagascar

MSI is one of the largest international family planning organizations in the world.
MSI delivers quality family planning and reproductive healthcare to millions of the world's poorest and most vulnerable women. MSI/Madagascar hired HNI for three separate initiatives. The first application collects monthly client data using SMS from a network of private sector doctors grouped together under the brand “Blue Star”. The second collects client satisfaction data using SMS from women who visited clinics affiliated with Marie Stopes International. The third project allows clinics operated by Marie Stopes to submit monthly reports via the Internet.
www.mariestopes.org

RTI International

RTI conducts research and provides technical services to government agencies, universities, foundations, private businesses, and other organizations. HNI and RTI worked together on two different initiatives. The first application allows community-based supervisors to report monthly activity data using SMS. The second application allows RTI employees to submit their supervisory reports and training results using SMS.
www.rti.org

Conservation International

CI is a nonprofit organization, which applies innovations in science, economics, policy and community participation to protect the Earth's biodiversity around the world. CI hired HNI to help build their internal capacity to collect small grants information using SMS. HNI also created a second application that allows National Parks Staff to use SMS to report on illegal activities in any of Madagascar’s protected areas.
www.conservation.org

National Bureau of Risk and Disaster Management

Catholic Relief Services (CRS) hired HNI to build the internal capacity of Madagascar’s National Bureau of Risk and Disaster Management (known by the French acronym BNGRC) to collect critical damage reports from post-disaster sites using SMS.
www.bngrc.mg

Ambatovy

Ambatovy is a large-tonnage, long-life nickel and cobalt mining enterprise located in Madagascar. It is the largest-ever foreign investment in the country and will soon rank among the largest nickel mining entities in the world. Ambatovy hired HNI to help collect grievance reports from the field.
www.ambatovy.com

fields.title: About us, partners in English
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Partners {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "about" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > About us > Partners {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

ABOUT US

  • Blog
  • Partners
  • Clients
  • HNI

An international partnership of private sector companies, academic institutions and non-governmental organizations are working collaboratively to create and manage DataWinners.com as an open-source project. Human Network International (HNI) and ThoughtWorks, Inc. lead the effort to make this mobile data collection service responsive to the needs of development organizations worldwide.

Our goal is to create a global community, working together to make mobile data collection better. Click here to access the code base. We encourage partners to contribute code and ideas so DataWinners will continue to innovate.

We want to thank our partners, and beta-testers featured here. They contribute significantly to our goal of offering an online, multi-channel, data collection platform to development organizations worldwide.

ThoughtWorks

Software development partner

A global IT consultancy that delivers custom software, software tools, consulting, and transformation services to Global 1000 companies. ThoughtWorks personnel in Pune, India wrote the majority of the code for both Mangrove and DataWinners.
www.thoughtworks.com

Mule Design

Design studio

Mule Design is a San Francisco-based design studio that created the intuitive, user-friendly DataWinners interface
www.muledesign.com

Modi Research Group

Software development partner

The Modi Research Groups leads Columbia University’s Earth Institute’s efforts that cut across energy, rural infrastructure and development. Staff of the Modi Research Group provided valuable code and advice to the Mangrove and DataWinners projects.
modi.mech.columbia.edu

Praekelt Foundation

Software development partner

Praekelt Foundation builds open source, scalable mobile technologies and solutions to improve the health and wellbeing of people living in poverty. The Mangrove project uses Vumi a scalable conversation engine for the delivery of SMS, Star Menu and chat messages to diverse audiences.
www.praekeltfoundation.org

Airtel Madagascar

Technical partner

Airtel Madagascar is the island’s largest provider of telecommunication services. Airtel/Madagascar provided telecommunications advice to the DataWinners project.
www.africa.airtel.com/madagascar/

UNICEF/Madagascar

Beta tester

The world's leading organization protecting the rights of children and young people. UNICEF in Madagascar is using DataWinners to collect nutrition data and information on local radio programming.
www.unicef.org

Catholic Relief Services/Madagascar

Beta tester

CRS is the international humanitarian agency of the Catholic community in the United States. CRS provides relief in emergency situations and helps people in the developing world break the cycle of poverty through community-based, sustainable development initiatives. CRS is using DataWinners to collect data on water and hygiene projects in remote areas in Northeastern Madagascar.
www.crs.org

PSI/Madagascar

Beta tester

PSI is a leading global health organization with programs targeting malaria, child survival, HIV and reproductive health. PSI is using DataWinners to collect data for a large adolescent reproductive health project and stock information for a wide range of public health products.
www.psi.org

Public Health

Family Planning
and Reproductive Health

In 2010, Marie Stopes Madagascar (MSM) began collecting and storing information sent in via mobile phone from doctors affiliated with its "BlueStar" network of medical clinics.

Using simple SMS technology, doctors in the network send in data regarding Family Planning services performed on a monthly basis.

All data is aggregated in a central database, accessible to headquarters staff, where it can be verified, filtered and exported for analysis.

Read more »

"Thanks to HNI, we could gather timely, accurate and complete data on a monthly basis and analyze which of our marketing efforts directly lead to spikes in clients seen.

We now have a much better idea where to spend our limited resources."
Miles Kemplay, Country Director of MSM

Public Health

Child and Maternal Healthcare


In 2010, the USAID-funded RTI/Santénet2 Project adopted a mobile phone reporting system to collect health services data delivered by the project.

Using HNI’s data collection and communication platform, RTI/Santénet 2 has collected reliable information regarding
  • Maternal health and family planning
  • Child malnutrition
  • Diarrhea, respiratory infection and malaria

Read more »

"Thanks to our partnership with HNI, and the hard work of our senior staff, we now have the data we need to report to USAID on macro-level indicators. "
Dr. Volkan Cakir, Chief of Party, The Santénet2 Project

HUMANITARIAN AID, Madagascar

Risk and Disaster Management


In 2010, the National Bureau for Risk and Disaster Management (known by the French acronym BNGRC) launched a new initiative to collect data electronically after a natural disaster.

Using SMS, local officials now send in their first post-cyclone data from the affected areas to headquarters. Managers in the capital, Antananarivo, can view the data in spreadsheets and maps and then make more informed decisions.

Read more »

"Now, communicating, processing and compiling the data is done quickly. We map our data, send messages to raise pre-disaster awareness and increase preparedness, access our collected data in real time and share it with other stakeholders."
BNGRC Webmaster/ Data Analyst

fields.title: Privacy and Policy in English
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Privacy and Policy {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Privacy and Policy {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

DataWinners’ Privacy Policies

We recognize the importance of your privacy and the protection of your data. This Privacy Policy strives to explain clearly DataWinners’ commitments to privacy. If you have questions, please contact us at support@datawinners.com.

Information DataWinners Collects Directly from You

Data can be collected and processed when our website is in operation by you. The following are approved methods of collection:

  1. During the Registration Process
    1. Organization Name and Development Sector
    2. Address
    3. City
    4. State
    5. Zip Code
    6. Country
    7. Office Phone Number
    8. name of Contact
    9. E-mail address
    10. Skype ID
  2. Payment and Billing
    1. Credit Card Number (if paying by Credit Card)
  3. Communication with DataWinners
    When you communicate with DataWinners or use certain DataWinners’ features, we collect and maintain the communication from you. These may include:
    1. Template Gallery
    2. User Forum
    3. Success Stories
    4. Customer Support
  4. When you Create Projects and Questionnaires
    Information you may provide that DataWinners collects includes:
    1. Names, phone numbers and locations of any Registered Data Senders and Subjects

Information that DataWinners Collects About You from Other Sources

  1. Analytical Tools:
    Traffic data, weblogs, location data, and any other communication can be collected. These details come from your visit to our site and any resource tools you use while on the site.
  2. Cookies:
    1. Cookies are used to collect general online usage by using a cookie file.
    2. If used this cookie file is downloaded without prompting. It will be placed on your hard drive with information transferred to the hard drive allowing the cookies to be used for data collection.
    3. A cookie is used to improve any services/ products, or overall website characteristic we offer you.
    4. All information gathered by cookies is purely statistical. No personal or identifying information is retained.
    5. Any computer has the option to decline cookies. Your web browser options include an “enable” button to decline cookies.
    6. By declining cookies you may be limiting your access to sections of our website.
  3. Information You Collect Using DataWinners
    1. You control the information that you collect using DataWinners
    2. DataWinners does not review your questionnaires, projects or collected data
    3. As such, you are solely responsible for ensuring that your use of DataWinners for collection of information from others complies with international and local laws.
  4. Storage of Information
    1. Information DataWinners collects from and about you is stored on DataWinners’ secure server space at www.linode.com in the United Kingdom and Salesforce.com
    2. Information you collect using DataWinners is stored on DataWinners’ secure server space at www.linode.com in the United Kingdom.
    3. Transmission of data on the Internet can never be ultimately secure. We do not and cannot guarantee security of information collected electronically or transmitted; however, we take all necessary steps to provide the best security available. As a result of our inability to guarantee safety, you are submitting information to us at your own risk. Where needed a password may be necessary to access areas of our site. You are responsible for the safety and confidentiality of the password you generate.
  5. Your Access to Information
    1. You may have access to your personal and financial information at any time and are free to make corrections to such information
    2. Upon cancellation or termination of your DataWinners’ account, you may request that all personal and financial information be deleted from DataWinners’ database.
    3. As long as your account is active, you may have access to the data you collect using DataWinners at any time by logging onto the DataWinners web site.
  6. Sharing Data you Collect Using DataWinners:
    1. You may choose to share data through various DataWinners’ features – by setting user access permissions and downloading data.
    2. You, however, are responsible to ensure that your sharing of data is authorized by relevant data privacy laws.
    3. For more detail regarding your usage rights, refer to DataWinners Terms and Conditions
  7. DataWinners’ Use of Your Information
    DataWinners may use the information collected from and about you in order to:
    1. Provide you with all contracted services, including contacting you with respect to customer support, billing and payment or other questions regarding your account
    2. Improve the DataWinners’ service and website.
    3. Manage the DataWinners service, including:
      1. usage
      2. screen for potentially illegal activity
    4. Enforce the Terms of Service, including Terms of Payment
  8. DataWinners’ Disclosure of Information you Gather Using DataWinners
    1. DataWinners will not view, release, share or distribute the data you gather via DataWinners Questionnaires.
    2. One exception is if DataWinners is compelled to release such information pursuant to a subpoena or other request. DataWinners will determine how to respond to such requests, if any, on a case-by-case basis.
  9. DataWinners’ Disclosure of your Personal Information
    DataWinners will not sell, release or distribute any of the information you provide regarding yourself or your organization with the following exceptions in which information may be disclosed:
    1. Sale of DataWinners or DataWinners’ Assets
    2. In response to legal action. DataWinners will determine how to respond to such requests, if any, on a case-by-case basis
  10. Third Party Links
    Links might be discovered on our site that belong to third parties. Any third party website on our site may have a privacy policy. You should check their terms. We do not accept liability or responsibility for their privacy policies, based on our lack of control over these third party links.
  11. Modification to Privacy Policy
    DataWinners reserves the right to modify this Privacy Policy and will provide all account holders notice of any changes.

{% endblock %}

fields.title: Success story, bngrc in english
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Risk and Disaster Management {% endblock %} {% block page_theme %} Humanitarian Aid, Madagascar {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "success" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Success Stories > Risk and Disaster Management {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

SUCCESS STORIES

  • Family Planning and Reproductive Health
  • Maternal and Child Health
  • Risk and Disaster Management

About the Project

In the event of a natural disaster, the National Bureau for Risk and Disaster Management (known by the French acronym BNGRC) is the entity responsible for coordinating programs and activities linked to emergency response and assistance. Additionally, the bureau is also responsible for preparedness and prevention to reduce the impact of disasters.

The Challenge

For several years, post-disaster data have been collected through either

  • landline phone
  • radio communication
  • hard copy paper reports (mainly for communities close to the BNGRC central office)

There are significant delays associated with collecting disaster data via these paper reports; in times when people need direct, immediate assistance, these lapses can be catastrophic. Moreover, the processing of information requires 30 minutes or longer for each report received.
Such information processing is time consuming, and the cost of telephone calls increased in parallel with the extent of the damages.

« Every year, an average of 500 villages are affected by cyclones, Madagascar’s most prominent natural disaster. The processing of information is time consuming, involves a lot of personnel, and delays the decision-making and the sending of response teams; however, in the meantime, the extent of the damages is increasing. It is even possible that there will be deaths before the emergency response team arrives », says Nianja Raonivelo, BNGRC Webmaster/Data Analyst.

Action Taken

In collaboration with the members of other disaster preparedness projects, BNGRC decided to modernize its post-disaster data collection infrastructure with an HNI-developed mobile phone data reporting platform. The goal is to provide alternatives to disaster-affected communities for reporting post-flood and cyclone information and to reduce the processing time of information that reaches BNGRC’s headquarters. The BNGRC equipped 1,700 reporters in at-risk communities.
The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) invested in an additional 300 mobile phones for the project. International partners such as CARE, CRS, ADRA and UNDP mobilized their field staff working in areas prone to cyclones and flooding, participated in the training of the reporters and lent various other types of support to this undertaking.

The Result

BNGRC’s mobile phone reporting system for disaster relief, prevention and management is currently operational. The system is considered affordable, reliable and robust enough to meet the organization’s needs in times of crisis.

“Now, communicating, processing and compiling the data is done quickly. We map our data, send messages to raise pre-disaster awareness and increase preparedness, access our collected data in real time and share it with other stakeholders ».


Nianja Raonivelo BNGRC Webmaster/ Data Analyst

About BNGRC


The National Bureau for Risk and Disaster Management (known by the French acronym BNGRC) of Madagascar is the entity responsible for coordinating activities for risk and disaster management, and for some hazards, the preparedness and prevention to reduce the impact of disasters.
www.bngrc.mg

fields.title: Success story, msi in english
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Family Planning and Reproductive Health {% endblock %} {% block page_theme %} Public Health, Madagascar {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "success" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Success Stories > Family Planning and Reproductive Health {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

SUCCESS STORIES

  • Family Planning and Reproductive Health
  • Maternal and Child Health
  • Risk and Disater Management

About the Project

Marie Stopes Madagascar (MSM) has partnered with more than 100 private doctors and clinics throughout Madagascar, collectively known as the BlueStar Network, to provide family planning and reproductive healthcare for low-income women and couples.

The Challenge

In the past, MSM collected data from each of the 100+ doctors using a paper-based system. However, MSM found this method error-prone, expensive and unreliable.
Data arrived at headquarters sporadically, making trend analysis impossible. Overall, MSM received less than half of all required reports. To expand the network and collect data from even more remote rural areas, MSM needed a new tool.

Action Taken

MSM hired HNI to build its own internal capacity to collect data electronically.
Together with HNI, MSM staff chose a list of important monthly indicators (e.g. client contraceptive choice by method). HNI built and installed the new application. Right away, MSM began collecting valuable data from the doctors.

The Result

Now, more than 95% of all doctors send in their monthly reports via SMS by the specified deadline, compared with less than half prior to HNI’s intervention.

“We needed timely, accurate and complete data on a monthly basis from our doctors.
Once we had a solid baseline over several months for each doctor, we started analyzing which of our marketing efforts directly led to spikes in clients seen.
Thanks to HNI, we now have a much better idea where to spend our limited resources.” - Miles Kemplay, Country Director of MSM.

MSM management noted 2 additional advantages to SMS-based data collection.

  1. Doctors report motivational benefits from the confirmation messages they receive in response to submitted data.
  2. Regular reporting via mobile phones has helped network members grow accustomed to using technology as a part of their professional lives.

“We have many ideas regarding how to use technology in our work…stay tuned!”


Miles Kemplay, Country Director of MSM

About MSM

Marie Stopes Madagascar is a not-for-profit, non-governmental organization that provides family planning and reproductive healthcare for low-income women and couples throughout Madagascar. They have 15 health centers, and more than 100 private sector doctors offering reproductive health services and consulting.
www.mariestopes.mg

fields.title: Success story, sn2 in english
fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Maternal and Child Health {% endblock %} {% block page_theme %} Public Health, Madagascar {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "success" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Success Stories > Maternal and Child Health {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

SUCCESS STORIES

  • Family Planning and Reproductive Health
  • Maternal and Child Health
  • Risk and Disaster Management

© RTI/Santénet2: A Community Health Worker with patient

About the Project

The Santénet2 project is a major public health initiative in Madagascar implemented by RTI International and funded by USAID.

The scale and scope of the project is enormous. The intervention zones covers over 60% of Madagascar and includes 6,000 villages located in mostly remote, rural areas.
Project staff has trained more than 12,000 community-based health workers to:

  • Improve child survival, maternal health, and nutrition;
  • Reduce unintended pregnancy and promote healthy reproductive behavior;
  • Reduce transmission and impact of HIV/AIDS

The Challenge

The RTI/Santénet2 project has major reporting requirements, yet Madagascar’s underdeveloped infrastructure makes data collection a challenge.
Every month, each of the 12,000 community-based health workers filled out a paper form summarizing their monthly results (e.g. Number of sick children visited).
Then, 200 supervisors visited 4-5 communes each month to summarize this data and email the results to RTI/Santénet2 headquarters.

Reporting rates were poor; less than 5% of all health data arrived at the project's headquarters. Early on, Dr. Volkan Cakir, Chief of Party, recognized a need for change: “From the beginning, we knew we had to innovate to be able to report on our success.”

Action Taken

Like much of Africa, Madagascar’s mobile telephone coverage is improving and most of the 200 supervisors own an inexpensive phone. RTI/Santénet2 staff decided to put mobile technology to work. They hired HNI to create a mobile phone reporting system and help them select 12 key indicators (e.g. Number of children diagnosed with Malaria). They trained the 200 supervisors to SMS monthly commune level aggregated data to RTI/Santenet2’s headquarters database.

The Result

Since launching the new data collection initiative in June 2010, 97% of the project's supervisors have reported data via SMS at least once. This is an impressive achievement compared to the 5% reporting rate before. Two-thirds of the supervisors now report consistently and each month the successful submission rate improves.

“Thanks to our partnership with HNI, and the hard work of our senior staff, we now have the data we need to report to USAID on macro-level indicators.
We no longer have to extrapolate; data from the field show our community health workers treated more than 100,000 cases of childhood illness in twelve months, and almost 80,000 women are using community based Family Planning services.”


Dr. Volkan Cakir, Chief of Party, The Santénet2 Project

About RTI

RTI International is an independent, nonprofit research institute that provides research and technical services to government and commercial clients worldwide.
www.rti.org

{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Case Studies {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "support" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_scss %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_js %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Support > Case Studies {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

SUPPORT

  • Case studies
  • Get Started
  • Find Answers (FAQs)
  • Ask Us

Osi is the program manager for a child nutrition project.
Click on each image below to see how Osi uses DataWinners for her data collection needs.



Summary Report
Individual Report
Supervisor Report

SUMMARY REPORTS

1. Replace Costly and Inefficient Paper-Based Data Collection

Osi has a problem: As program manager of a large child malnutrition project, she cannot get timely, accurate and complete data from Nutrition Agents at each of her Feeding Centers.

2. Upgrade to Mobile Data Collection

Among the 3 options (Web, SMS, Smartphone) Osi chooses to collect her data using SMS. She reviews her paper-based monthly summary report form, talks with staff and decides:

  • Who she wants to collect data from (Nutrition Agents)
  • The subject of her questionnaire (Feeding Centers)
  • The key questions she wants her Nutrition Agents to answer using SMS (example: How many children did you weigh last month?)

She creates the Questionnaire using DataWinners’ friendly Questionnaire Builder. DataWinners automatically creates the corresponding

  1. Data Base
  2. SMS Questionnaire
  3. Web Form
  4. Smartphone Questionnaire

3. Train the Data Senders

Osi prints out the Questionnaire and uses it to train her Nutrition Agents to send in monthly summary reports using SMS.

4. Use DataWinners to Send Reminders

Osi sets an automatic reminder to be sent to all Nutrition Agents who haven’t yet submitted their report.

5. View your Data from DataWinners Website

The day after the submission deadline, Osi logs in to her DataWinners account and sees complete monthly reports from all 100 Feeding Centers. For the first time, Osi has all her data, on time.

6. Share Your Data

Osi provides her supervisor with a link to the monthly summary data.

7. Make better Decisions

Her supervisor is thrilled to have the information. Osi and the supervisor review the data and decide to make changes at several Feeding Centers.
Osi sends all 100 Nutrition Agents an SMS using DataWinners to congratulate them on sending in their information and meeting project goals.

INDIVIDUAL RECORDS

1. Collect multiple Reports simultaneously

In addition to the Monthly Summary Reports, Osi also wants her Nutrition Agents to send in key data after each child’s visit to a Feeding Center.

2. Improve the Quality of your Data

Osi creates a second data collection project in her DataWinners account. She reviews her paper-based Feeding Center Visit Report form, talks with staff and decides:

  • Who she wants to collect data from (Nutrition Agents)
  • The subject of her questionnaire (Each Child who visits)
  • The key questions she wants her Nutrition Agents to answer (example: How much does the child weigh in kilograms?)

She creates the Questionnaire using DataWinners’ friendly Questionnaire Builder. DataWinners automatically creates the corresponding

  1. Data Base
  2. SMS Questionnaire
  3. Web Form
  4. Smartphone Questionnaire

3. Register each Child in DataWinners

Osi uses her DataWinners account to create a simple registration form for each child who visits a feeding center:

  1. What is the child's first name?
  2. What is the child's last name?
  3. Child's date of birth?
  4. Mother's telephone number?

Once the Nutrional Agents send in the answers to these registration questions, DataWinners generates a unique identification number for each child.

4. Train the Data Senders

Osi trains the Data Senders how to send in data using Web, SMS and Smartphone.

Each Nutrition Agent chooses the most convenient way to send in the individual records.

5. View Data from DataWinners Website

On a daily basis, Osi can review the feeding center visit reports in real time from all 100 of her Feeding Centers. Osi can identify each severely malnourished child and work with Nutrition Agent on a recovery plan.

6. Compare Results over Time

Using DataWinners data analysis tools, Osi can track the progress of each child over time.

SUPERVISOR REPORTS

1. Quality Assurance Data

Osi wants to collect quality assurance data from her Regional Supervisors after each visit to a Feeding Center.

2. Create a New Project in DataWinners

Osi creates a third data collection project in her DataWinners account. She reviews her paper-based Feeding Center Quality Assurance Report form, talks with staff and decides:

  • Who she wants to collect data from (Regional Supervisors)
  • The subject of her questionnaire (Feeding Center)
  • The key questions she wants her Supervisors to answer (example: What overall grade, out of five do you give this Feeding Center?)

She creates the Questionnaire using DataWinners’ friendly Questionnaire Builder. DataWinners automatically creates the corresponding

  1. Data Base
  2. SMS Questionnaire
  3. Web Form
  4. Smartphone Questionnaire

3. Register Each Feeding Center in DataWinners

Osi uses her DataWinners account to create a simple registration form for each feeding center:

  • What is name of Feeding Center?
  • Where is Feeding Center located?

Once Osi answers these questions, DataWinners generates a unique identification number for each Feeding Center

4. Train the Data Senders

Osi equips her Supervisors with Android Smartphones and trains them to send in data using DataWinners Smartphone application.

5. View Data from DataWinners Website

On a daily basis, Osi can review the Feeding Center Quality Assurance reports in real time. Osi can identify which Feeding Centers require immediate assistance.

6. Compare Results over Time

Using DataWinners data analysis tools, Osi can track the progress of each Feeding Center over time.

SUPPORT

  • Quick Start Services
  • Guides & Tutorials
  • Find Answers
  • Ask Us
Browse our list of Frequently Asked Questions.


General Information

What is DataWinners?

DataWinners is the first completely integrated, mobile data collection service. DW enables you to collect data via SMS anywhere, with any phone. And because your DataWinners' subscription includes bulk pre-paid SMS, we eliminate time-consuming negotiations with telephone carriers and SMS Gateways.

How Does it Work

When you sign up for a DataWinners' subscription, you receive: 1) access to the DataWinners website; 2) a local telephone number in your project country and; 3) a bulk SMS package.
From the DataWinners website you:

  1. Design and build data collection questionnaires (forms) for your project
  2. Create training materials that teach your staff how to format SMS responses to your questionnaires
  3. Register data senders and subjects
  4. Create automatic reminders that send SMS messages reminding staff to send in data

In the field:
Your staff collect answers to your questionnaires and SMS the answers to the local number provided by DataWinners. The service works with any phone that can send SMS

Back at DataWinners:
You have access to view, analyze and download your data in real time. You can share your data by setting account and user permissions, enabling others in your organization to have immediate access to critical project information.

What can you do with DataWinners?

Anything. Examples of some DataWinners deployments include:
Stock monitoring (medication, mosquito nets)
Monthly activity summaries (patients seen at a health center)
Client satisfaction surveys
Sales Receipt collections
Water-point monitoring

What makes DataWinners different?

DataWinners allows you to collect data in the most challenging environments where paper based systems are costly and often fail.

Unlike mobile data collection toolkits that require configuration and software expertise, you can use DataWinners with no IT experience.

DataWinners has taken on the hardest part of SMS data collection – negotiation with telecoms. Your DataWinners subscription covers the costs of SMS data collection including a local phone number and pre-paid SMS.

How much does DataWinners cost?

Our goal is to offer DataWinners services in any country in the world for less than $1,000/month. See our Pricing Page here. This price includes access to the DataWinners do-it-yourself data collection tools, a packet of SMS along with a local telephone number and virtually unlimited data collecting. Costs vary in each country according to the rates we’ve negotiated with the telecommunications operators.

Where can I use DataWinners?

Anywhere a mobile phone can send SMS. For a complete list of countries and our rollout plan see our pricing page here. You can access your DataWinners account from a web browser anywhere.

Can I try DataWinners without subscribing?

Yes. DataWinners offers a free 30 day trial account that allows you to experiment with the full features of DataWinners. You can build online questionnaires, collect an unlimited amount of data using the Internet and even try data submission using SMS.
Click here for more information

.

What type of mobile phones work with DataWinners?

Any SMS-enabled phone in the world can send in data.

Can I get help?

Absolutely. Consult our how-to pages and tutorials or contact us at support@DataWinners.com

What languages does DataWinners support?

The DataWinners website is currently available in English and French. Choose your language on the top, right hand corner of any page. We plan to add additional languages soon. You can build your questionnaire in any language. Users can also specify the language (English, French or Malagasy) of automatic Success and Error messages sent back to Data Senders.

Is this open source? Who is the code base available to?

An international partnership of private sector companies, academic institutions and non-governmental organizations are working collaboratively to create and manage DataWinners.com as an open-source project. Human Network International (HNI) and ThoughtWorks, Inc. lead the effort to make this mobile data collection service responsive to the needs of development organizations worldwide.

DataWinners hosted service is one of the first applications built using the Mangrove data collection framework, itself an open source project that develops core tools for mobile data collection, aggregation, analysis, and visualization targeting SMS, Web, J2ME and Android via XForms. The Mangrove initiative is collaboration of ThoughtWorks, Inc, the Modi Research Lab at Columbia University and HNI.

The goal of these open-sourced projects is to create a global community, working together to make mobile data collection better. The entire code base for DataWinners and Mangrove is available for download here. We encourage partners to contribute code and ideas so DataWinners and Mangrove continue to innovate.

Can I send in my data using smartphones?

DataWinners began with SMS because our clients needed a tool that worked in the most resource challenged locations in the world. Through its work with Mangrove, DataWinners is building tools for J2ME and Android for release in future versions of DataWinners, planned for the first quarter of 2012

Data Senders

Who is a Data Sender?

A person who sends in data using SMS or Internet is a Data Sender. With DataWinners you give permission to people to send in data by first registering your Data Senders. Then DataWinners will recognize Data Senders by their telephone numbers or email addresses.

Should I Register Data Senders?

Yes. Registration is required. During registration you will be asked to include the telephone number that the Data Sender will use to send SMS. When registered Data Senders SMS in data, DataWinners will recognize the registered telephone number and accept the data. Any SMS from a non-registered number will be rejected and the Data Sender will receive an automatic error message.

Do I need to register my Data Sender's telephone number in a specific format?

Yes. When registering a Data Sender, include the country code in the telephone number and omit all spaces and special characters. For example, in Madagascar, the phone number 033 12 345 67 would be registered as: 261331234567.

Do I need to register my Data Sender's telephone number in a specific format?

Yes. When registering a Data Sender, include the country code in the telephone number and omit all spaces and special characters. For example, in Madagascar, the phone number 033 12 345 67 would be registered as: 261331234567.

Can a Data Sender self-register from the field using SMS?

No. DataWinners will not accept submissions from non-registered telephones. However, a registered Data Sender can register a new Data Sender in the system by sending in the following SMS (omit all <>):

Reg .t reporter .n <name of Data Sender>l .m <mobile phone number> .l <location> .g <gps coordinates of data sender> (GPS Coordinates are optional)

Do I need to register my Data Sender for each new project that I create?

No. Once registered, a Data Sender is able to send in data for all current and future projects. However, Data Senders receive reminder messages only for projects for which they are associated. You can associate a Data Sender to a particular project by first clicking on the Data Sender link at the top of the page. Then select the data senders you want associated with your project. Then, choose the “Add to project” option from the drop down list in the “Actions” box at the top of the page. Finally choose which projects you’d like to associate your Data Senders with.

Does my 'Data Sender' need to include his or her unique ID when submitting data?

No. DataWinners will identify each Data Sender by their registered phone number.

What are success and error messages?

Each time a Data Sender submits data, DataWinners will evaluate the SMS and automatically send back a message. If the SMS contains any errors, DataWinners will send back an error message specifying the mistake made. If the SMS contains no errors, then DataWinners will send a success message back along with a summary of the submitted answers. The Data Sender can then review the summary and re-submit in case of any inadvertent errors.

How do I change the language of the success and error messages that my Data Senders receive?

Choose the Success and error message language on the Define Project step. To change the language of these messages while still in the Test State of the project, click the "Edit this Project" link from the project overview page and choose the new language. Once a project is in its Active state, the message language is fixed and cannot be changed.

What languages can my Data Senders receive their Success and Error messages in?

In the current release of DataWinners, Success and Error messages can be sent in English, French and Malagasy.

Can I customize the Success and Error messages or add a new language or dialect?

In the current release of DataWinners, Success and Error Messages are not editable or customizable. However, we plan to implement these features in upcoming releases of DataWinners.



Subjects

What is a 'Subject'?

A Subject is what your questionnaire is about; a specific person, place, thing or event on which Data Senders report.

In many cases, the Data Sender interacts with a subject, then sends in an individual report about the interaction:

A doctor examines a baby. In this case, the subject is the baby.
A supervisor measures the quality of care at a clinic. The subject is the clinic
An engineer measures the flow rate of a water pump. The subject is the water pump.
A sales person sells products to a retailer: The subject is the retailer.

What is the difference between a Summary Report and an Individual Report about a specific subject?

Data collection projects can be grouped into two broad categories: 1) Summary Reports and; 2) Individual Reports about a specific subject . With DataWinners, you can collect data for either, or both.

Summary Reports
Examples:
  • A community health worker sends in a monthly activity report
    • (example question: How many babies did you weigh last month?)
  • A young woman answers polling questions
    • (Example question: Do you have access to clean water?).
DataWinners will display your data according to each Data Sender:
DATA SENDER'S NAME WHAT MONTH AND YEAR ARE YOU REPORTING ON? HOW MANY BABIES DID YOU WEIGH LAST MONTH? HOW MANY BABIES WERE SERVERLY MALNURISHED?
SHANNON 11.2011 1213 217
DAVID 11.2011 756 78

Individual Reports about a specific subject

With DataWinners, you can go beyond collecting summaries; You can collect individual reports about a specific subject. You can register people, places and things and give each a unique ID number that allows you to: 1) create detailed questionnaires about them (like a medical record); 2) create several different questionnaires about each subject (if your register a clinic, you can create one questionnaire to monitor stock and another to measure the quality of care at the clinic).

Examples:

A doctor examines a baby. In this case, the subject is the baby.
A supervisor measures the quality of care at a clinic. The subject is the clinic
An engineer measures the flow rate of a water pump. The subject is the water pump.

In each case, the Data Senders (in other words, people in the field) must first identify the specific “subject” (baby/clinic/water pump).

For example, the Data Sender would first answer the question: “What baby are you reporting on?”

All subsequent questions would be about the baby. (Example: “How much did the baby weigh?”)

DataWinners will display your data according to each Subject (Baby):

SCREEN SHOT OF ANALYSIS PAGE
BABY'S NAME WHEN DID THE BABY VISIT THE FEEDING CENTER? HOW MUCH DID THE BABY WEIGH IN GRAMS WHAT WAS THE HEIGHT OF THE BABY IN CENTIMETERS?
AVERY-MAE 28.11.2011 2298 65
AMELIA VO 02.12.2011 2456 69

To facilitate data collection and improve accuracy, you can register each individual Subject in DataWinners prior to collecting data about them. Each Subject will receive a unique identification number. Data Senders then use the Subject’s unique ID when they report on the results of a visit to (or from) the Subject.

Register each Subject with their geographical location and DataWinners will display each subject individually on a map.

What is the difference between a Subject Type and an Individual Subject?

A Subject Type is a general label. For example, you create the Subject Type "Clinic." You could then register the following individual Subjects:

  • North Clinic
  • South Clinic
  • East Clinic
  • West Clinic

What are the advantages to register 'Subjects' for my projects?

To collect individual reports about specific subjects, you have two choices.

  1. Each time, you can ask your Data Senders to send in background information about the subject (Example: What is the baby’s name? Where does the baby live?)
Or
  1. Register the background information about the subject first, then going forward have your Data Senders identify each subject using a unique number (example: “What is the unique identification number of the baby?” Answer: bab072)

There are three important advantages to using unique identification numbers:

  1. Improve the quality of your data. Data Senders frequently make spelling mistakes (Example: A Data Sender spells a baby’s name “Avery” during the first visit, then “Avary” during the second). When spelling mistakes happen, you have to “clean” your data by determining if “Avery” and “Avary” are two different babies, or the same baby. Mistakes happen less frequently with unique identification numbers.
  2. Make data collection easier by reducing the number of questions. It’s easier for your Data Senders to answer one question (what is the baby’s identification number?) rather than, say, four background questions (1. What is the baby’s name? 2. Where does the baby live? 3. How old is the baby? 4. What is the mother’s name?)
  3. Once subjects are registered in DataWinners, you can collect a variety of data about them. You may want to collect several different individual reports for one subject (example: a report when the baby is seen at a nutritional center and a second report when the community agent visits the baby at home). After registering the baby with DataWinners, your Data Senders can use the baby’s unique identification number for multiple questionnaires.

If you want to register your subjects with DataWinners, the first step is to identify the subject type (Example: Patient, Clinic, Water Pump).

Subjects are People (Patient, Farmer, Employee); Places (Region, District, Commune); Things (Health Center, Retail Shop, Water Pump) or Events (Training, Performance, Public Gathering)

You can choose an existing Subject Type already registered with your DataWinners account, or specify a new Subject Type.

Once you choose a subject type (example: Baby), you will see this question appear in your questionnaire builder: “What baby are you reporting on?”.

In a later step, you will:

  1. Create your subject registration questionnaire (with the background questions you want for each subject)
  2. Register a list of your subjects with DataWinners so each is assigned a unique identification number.

Can a Data Sender register a subject from the field using SMS?

Yes. Data Senders can register new Subjects in the field. Use the following format (omit all <>):

Reg .t <type of subject> .n <name of Subject> .m <mobile phone number of Subject> .l <location of Subject> .g <gps coordinates of Subject>



Data Analysis

What do the pins on the map represent?

On any map, the pins represent either the registered Data Senders or the registered Subjects. If the project type is a Summary Report, then each pin on the map corresponds to one registered Data Sender. For Individual Reports about a Specific Subject, each pin on the map corresponds to one registered Subject.

Why aren’t all of my registered Data Senders or Subjects on the map?

Only Data Senders and Subjects registered with their geographic location are displayed on the map.

If you do not see a Data Sender or Subject on the map, it is likely that an error occurred when entering its coordinates or location during registration. Please review the registered Subject/Data Sender's GPS coordinates via the All Subjects/All Data Senders lists.

How do I add or delete a record that a Data Sender has submitted?

Add a record via the "Web Submission" link from the "Data" tab for any project. To delete a data record, click on the "Submission Log" page for the project, select the data record you wish to delete by clicking on the corresponding box in the left-most column, and select "Delete" from the Actions drop down menu.

What does the 'Submission Status' column refer to on the "Submission Log" page?

The Submission Status column indicates whether an incoming SMS was error free and accepted by the system, or contained one or more errors and was rejected by the system. The term "True" indicates the SMS submission was error free and accepted by the system. The term "False" indicates the SMS submission contained errors and was rejected by the system.

The intention of displaying the "False" submissions is to serve as a diagnostic tool to help you identify what issues or problems your Data Senders are having when they send in their data.

What does the "Deleted Record" column refer to on the "Submission Log" page?

The Deleted Record column indicates whether a data record was deleted by the user. The deleted record still appears in the “Submission Log” page, but does not appear on the “Analysis” page.

The term "False" indicates that the data record has not been deleted, and is therefore included in the calculations/aggregations on the analysis page. The term "True" indicates that the record has been deleted and is therefore not included in the calculations/aggregations on the analysis page.



Technical FAQs

Where is DataWinners hosted?

The system is currently hosted with Linode in their London, UK facility. Linode is an excellent virtual/cloud provider. Their website can be found here.

Where is my data stored?

Your data is stored on secure servers at Linode.com in the United Kingdom

What is the technology stack behind DataWinners?

Database CouchDB
Language Python
Application Framework Django
Key JavaScript Librairies jQuery
GIS Subsystem PostGIS, OpenLayers
Messaging Layer Vumi

Can the code be modified or manipulated?

Yes We encourage partners to contribute code and ideas so DataWinners and Mangrove continue to innovate.

What is the SMS interface built around?

DataWinners uses Vumi, an open source messaging transport created by the Praekelt Foundation for core messaging services. Vumi can be interfaced with any number of SMS gateway providers and Mobile Network Operators (MNOs). In Madagascar, DataWinners integrates directly with Airtel via SMPP (as supported by Vumi). We also have integrations with gateway providers in India and Clickatell in the US.

How does DataWinners interface with local providers?

We sign agreements with mobile operators and SMS aggregators to connect DataWinners to every cell phone in the world. This means in a matter of a days, we can activate DataWinners in any country in the world.

What browsers does DataWinners support?

  1. Internet Explorer 7 and newer versions
  2. Firefox 3.0 and newer versions
  3. Safari 5.1 and newer versions
{% endblock %}

fields.content:
{% extends 'public_secondary.html' %} {% block page_title %} Support {% endblock %} {% load dw_tabs %} {% block body %} {% activetab "main_nav" "support" %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_scss %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_js %} {{ block.super }} {% endblock %} {% block page_breadcrumbs %} Home > Support > Get started > How to Create a Project {% endblock %} {% block main_content %}

How to create Project


<< Back to Get Started Download: PDF, 14 pages, 1.4 MB
<- Previous page Next page -> Table of Contents

Table of Contents

  1. WHAT IS A DATAWINNERS PROJECT

  2. HOW TO CREATE A PROJECT

    • Fill out the Basic Information

      • Name & Description
      • Language for your Data Senders
      • A Summary Report vs. an Individual Report
      • Device

    • Create your Questionnaire

      • Overview
      • Questionnaire Code
      • Pre-defined Questions
      • Your Questions
      • Save & Create your Project

  3. NEXT STEPS

  4. THIS MIGHT ALSO INTEREST YOU

1 What is a DataWinners Project?

DataWinners is an online do-it-yourself mobile data collection service. No matter what sector you work in, DataWinners can help you collect and analyze the data you need for any kind of project. Here are some examples:

Summary Reports

  1. A community health worker sends in a monthly activity report
    Example question: How many babies did you weigh last month?
  2. A young woman answers polling questions
    Example question: Do you have access to clean water?

Individual Reports about a Specific Subject

With DataWinners, you can go beyond collecting summaries; you can collect individual reports about a specific Subject.

Subjects are people (children under five), places (Districts), things (Health Clinics) or events (Trainings) that you want to collect data about.

Using DataWinners, you can register your Subjects and give each a unique ID number so you can:

  1. Create detailed Questionnaires about them (like a medical record)
  2. Create several different Questionnaires about each Subject (if your register a clinic, you can create a Questionnaire to monitor stock and another to measure the quality of care at the clinic)

Examples:

  • A doctor examines a baby and sends in a medical record
  • A supervisor measures the quality of care at a clinic
  • An engineer measures the flow rate of a water pump

With DataWinners you can create a project to collect data for these projects and many more.

What are the Main Features

For each DataWinners project you can

  • Create a Questionnaire with the key data you want to collect
  • Register your Data Senders (the people who send you the data)
  • Register your Subjects (the specific topic of your Questionnaire e.g. patients, schools, villages, water pumps)
  • Specify automatic Reminders to remind your Data Senders to send in their data


Example As program manager of a large child malnutrition project, Osi wants her Nutritional Agents in the field to send in key data after each child’s visit to a Feeding Center.

She reviews her current paper-based Feeding Center Visit Report form, talks with staff and decides:
  1. Who she wants to collect data from (her Nutritional Agents are the Data Senders)
  2. The subject of her questionnaire (Each Child who visits)
  3. Which key questions she wants her Nutritional Agents to answer via SMS (example: How much does the child weigh in kilograms?)
 Her next step is to create the Questionnaire in DataWinners.

2 How to Create a Project

Every time you sign in to DataWinners (www.datawinners.com/login), you will land on the Dashboard.

This page gives you an overview of all your projects and lets you create a new project. Think of each DataWinners’ “Project” as a single questionnaire.


1
Create a new Project

Click on the Button Create a new Project to start your project.

2.1 Fill out the Basic Information

Give us some basic information about your project.

2.1.1 Name & Description

DataWinners stores project by the Project Name. This way you can keep track of all your data collection projects running at the same time.

1
Name your Project

Give your project a short, descriptive name so you can identify it among a list of all projects.

2
Add a Description optionnal

Write a description so others can understand the goal of your project.

2.1.2 Language for your Data Senders

Your Data Senders (the people who send in answers to your Questionnaire) will receive automatic Confirmation and Error messages from DataWinners based on their submission.

Choose a language for these messages.

1
Choose a Language

 

2.1.3 A Summary Report vs. an Individual Report

Choose between collecting Summary Reports or Individual Reports about a specific subject.

Don’t worry, if this sounds too complicated, you can decide later. Just choose the Summary Reports option for now.

Summary Report

Choose this option if you want answers to a basic list of questions.

Summary Osi needs to collect a monthly activity report from each of her Nutritional Agents
She asks her Data Senders the following questions:
  1. What month and year are you reporting on?
  2. How many babies did you weigh last month?
  3. How many babies were severely malnourished?

DataWinners will display her data according to each Data Sender:
Data Sender’s name What month and year are you reporting on? How many babies did you weigh last month? How many babies were severely malnourished?
Nirina Rakotobe 11.2011 1213 217
Jacqueline Rajolina 11.2011 756 78
       

Individual Reports about a Specific Subject

Individual Reports are about specific Subjects. Examples:

  • A doctor examines a baby. In this case, the Subject is the baby.
  • A supervisor measures the quality of care at a clinic. The Subject is the clinic
  • An engineer measures the flow rate of a water pump. The Subject is the water pump.

These specific Subjects are the topic of your data collection questionnaires. Subjects are often

  • People (Patients, Farmers, Children under five, Employees)
  • Things (Health clinics, Retail Shops, Water Pumps)
  • Places (Region, District, Commune, Village)
  • Events (Training, Performance, Public gathering)

In each case, the person reporting on the assessment (Data Sender) must first tell you which specific Subject he is reporting on (Example Question: What water pump are you reporting on? - Answer: wp003).

Example Osi needs key data after each child’s visit to a Feeding Center. She asks her Data Senders (Nutrition Agents) the following questions:
  1. What baby are you reporting on?
    (Note, every baby has been registered and has a unique number)
  2. How much did the baby weigh in grams?
  3. What was the height of the baby in centimeters?

DataWinners will display her data according to each Subject:
Baby’s Number Baby’s Name When did the baby visit the feeding center? How much did the baby weigh in grams? What was the height of the baby in centimeters?
082452 AVERY-MAE 28.11.2011 2298 65
062475 AMELIA VO 02.12.2011 2456 69
         

1
Choose between a Summary Report or an Individual Report about a specific Subject

Click on the Link Add another Question

2
Choose a Subject Type (For the Individual Report only)

  • Choose a Subject Type. Select an existing Subject Type from a previous DataWinners Project
  • Add your own new Subject Type. Example: Feeding Centers

2.1.4 Device

Devices are important because you can choose the communication channel people will use to send you your data.

Your choice depends on two questions:

  1. How much data do you need to collect?
  2. What devices do people already have?

SMS is an efficient data collection channel for questionnaires with less than 20 questions and where Data Senders have no Internet access. For more extensive data collection needs, we recommend using a Web Form (Internet).

If any of your Data Senders have (or will have) access to the Internet, we recommend adding the WEB channel. They can then choose either SMS or WEB to send you the data.

Depending on what channels you choose, DataWinners will create automatically a printout version of the SMS Questionnaire and an online form for your Web Questionnaire.

1
Choose Devices

SMS is the default and always available. Add Web to have both channels available. Don’t worry; you can always change your mind later.

2
Continue to the next page

 

2.2 Create your Questionnaire

The Questionnaire is the heart of every data collection project in DataWinners. Here you define what information you want to collect. Ask yourself 2 questions:

  1. What key data do I need to collect from the field to gain insight and make the right decisions?
  2. How can I formulate the question so my Data Senders understand what I want from them?
Example Project Osi wants to monitor the nutritional status of individual children. After each visit, Osi asks her Nutritional Agents to send in answers to these questions:
  • What is the unique identification number for the child?
  • How old is the child in months?
  • How much does the child weigh in kilograms?

2.2.1 Overview

Before you start, let us explain what you can do with the Questionnaire Builder.

A. Questionnaire Code

Every Questionnaire has a unique Code. Data Senders start their SMS message with this code so DataWinners knows which Questionnaire the Data Sender is answering.
See Chapter 0

B. Pre-defined Questions

We suggest some messages you might want to use. You can delete them if they don’t fit your project.
See Chapter 0

C. Add your own Questions

Add your own project-specific questions for your Data Senders (e.g. field staff) to answer.
See Chapter 2.2.4

D. SMS Counter

Keep track of how many characters your Data Senders need to answer your questions using SMS.

2.2.2 Questionnaire Code

DataWinners uses this unique code to correctly identify your SMS Questionnaire.

By using Questionnaire Codes, your organization can collect multiple data sets simultaneously using a single telephone number. Your Questionnaire Code will appear on the printed version of your Questionnaire. This Code is the first thing your Data Senders type in the SMS.

Example Project Osi creates a Questionnaire for her Child MalNutrion project. She and her colleagues use the abbreviation CMN. So she uses CMN for her Questionnaire Code.
1
Define a Questionnaire Code

Enter a combination of 3-6 letters and/or numbers (or both). Your Data Senders will enter this code first when sending in their data using SMS. Example: CMN

2.2.3 Pre-defined Questions

Based on your decisions on the previous step, DataWinners suggest questions you might want to use for your data collection.

Which subject are you reporting on?

If you have chosen to create an Individual Report about a specific Subject (see Chapter 2.1.3) you need to ask your Data Senders which specific Subject (e.g. Child) they are reporting on.

Example As program manager of a large child malnutrition project, Osi wants her Nutritional Agents in the field to send in key data after each child’s visit to a Feeding Center.

In DataWinners, Osi chooses “Individual Reports about a Specific Subject” and adds the Subject Type “Child”.

DataWinners automatically suggests, “Which child are you reporting on?” as the first question in the Questionnaire Builder.

Osi understands the importance of this question and decides to keep the “Which child are you reporting on?” question in her questionnaire.
1
Specify pre-defined Question Text

Change the question text if you don’t like our suggestion.

What is the reporting period for the activity?

Many projects have a specific reporting period. A good example is a monthly activity report.

Example The Nutritional Agents send in a Visit Report directly after each visit. They don’t have a specific reporting period.

Osi deletes this question, as it does not add any value to her project. She replaces it with, “What date did the child visit the Feeding Center”?
1
Specify Question

Customize the text to your reporting period. Example: e.g. What month and year are you reporting on?

2
Select a Date Format

Select the Date Format your Data Senders are most comfortable with. Example: 12.2011

2.2.4 Your Questions

Now specify your key questions for your Data Senders. Choose the kind of answer you want from your Data Senders (e.g. a number or date) and add restrictions to prevent them from sending in wrong data (example: the number must be between 0-10).

Feel free to experiment. You can always edit your questions later.

Example To see if a child is severely malnourished, Osi needs to know the age and the weight of a child. She specifies her first question: How old is the child in months?

The children at the Feeding Centers are between 0-60 months old. Osi specifies that the answer must be a number from 0-60.
1
Add a Question

Click on the Link Add another Question

2
Change Question Text

Specify your question. Example: How old is the child in months?

3
Select an Answer Type

Select the type of answer you want from your Data Senders. Example: A number (for the age of the child)

4
Add Restrictions

Add a restriction if needed. Min=0 and Max=60 as a child is always between 0-60 months old

5
View Automatic Instructions

These instructions explain the answer restrictions you set for your question (Example: “Answer must be a number between 0-60”). They are meant to help the Data Sender and increase the accuracy of your data. When you print the Questionnaire and give it to your Data Senders, these instructions will appear below each question.

2.2.5 Save & Create your Project

Once you are finished adding all your questions, click the yellow Save and Create button at the bottom of the screen. Don’t worry; you can always change your decisions at a later time

1
Save & Create Project

Click on the button Save & Create Project

3 Next steps

Now that you have created your project, you can get familiar with the rest of the features DataWinners has to offer.

A. What’s next

Review our Next Steps to enhance your project.

B. Test the Questionnaire

See if you can send in data for your Questionnaire

C. Edit Project Settings

Not happy with your earlier decisions? Change them.

4 This might also interest you

Please have a look around on our Website: www.datawinners.com

This might also interest you

  • What is DataWinners
  • Case Studies (Under Support)
  • Overview Video (Under Support -> Get Started)

{% endblock %}
